column4: So, is there any way in Ubuntu to assign an extra IP address to the loopback interface?

I am having a hard time finding an example of exactly what needs to be entered there to enable it (preferably without rendering the network subsystem unusable :) - hence my reluctance to experiment without a clear baseline to work from)
What is it exactly you are trying to do?
I'll do a pastebin, just a sec
Consulting with someone at work first, if we still can't solve it I'll bring it up with a pastebin :)

Well, if you're trying to do a Public IP for the use as a VIP from a load balancer/director, then there's more to it than simply binding a new IP to the loopback, because that IP /WILL/ get advertised via ARP, by default.
Which, of course, can and will cause an IP conflict.

the subject containing the IP is unreachable by the machine I'm trying to access it from, so I want to "pretend" it's accessible. I only need it for one small thing, so it's essentially just a mock server
Then you want to bind it to the actual ethernet device, not loopback.

But I don't want the IP to be visible to other machines on the network, I only want it to be visible to localhost. That's why I've been looking at loopback. I just need to say "hey, port 80 on this IP address points at these files". Like I said, there is OS X functionality that does this using BSD's ifconfig, I just want to replicate that in ubuntu
OKay, so, like I said, even bound to loopback, it WILL advertise in ARP, by default, so it will expose it.
Not really. What you're asking is rather common.
http://pastebin.com/0SpBQ9yu  -- This is what you need for /etc/sysctl.d/##-somefile   so that the IP won't broadcast out eth0 (or whatever you change ethX's to in this)
Alright, thanks for the pastebin, that will be very helpful :)
Now, do you want the interfaces example to go with it? It's /really/ easy.
